Usually the way to find humor in a horrific event is to wait a long time.
Take the Third Reich.
There have been some successful efforts: Hogan's Heroes, The Producers - but they came years after Hitler's fall.
Imagine telling some of those jokes about Hitler even as swastikas dominated Berlin.
Well, the truth is, that's what happened.
A new book explores the history of humor in Germany under Adolph Hitler.
The English translation of the German title is Heil Hitler: The Pig Is Dead.
It's also a documentary film.
The author and filmmaker is Rudolf Herzog, and he joins us now from his home in Berlin.
Welcome to TALK OF THE NATION.
Hello there.
And I understand first of all, the title of your book - that's a joke.
That is correct.
It's actually a joke about Hitler and his chauffeur driving across the countryside, and bang, they run into a pig.
They run over a pig, the pig is dead.
And Hitler says to the chauffeur we've got to confess this to the farmer and sends him off to the farmer to apologize.
But the man doesn't come back for 15 minutes, 20 minutes.
He's away for an hour, comes back totally drunk, and he's got a basket with sausages.
It's the middle of the war, and he's got champagne and everything.
And Hitler says well for God's sakes, what did you tell the farmer?
And the chauffeur says I only said Heil Hitler, the pig is dead, and then they gave me all these presents.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Which is actually pretty funny.
But the Nazi regime itself was really -it's been characterized as humorless.
Well, it doesn't mean that the people living under this regime were humorless.
There were lots of jokes, many of which - I don't know - I think even sort of expressed affection for the people in charge.
They're only outwardly critical.
For instance, there were a lot of jokes about Goering, the second in charge, who was very fat, and he had all these medals.
And they would say you know, he had his medals remodeled in rubber, you know, so he wouldn't have to take them off the bathtub, and so on - these kind of jokes.
But they're essentially harmless.
But humor got quite bleak, got quite hard and stark in the time of the war when the war was coming home to Germany.
And one assumes that Germany's Jews told different jokes than other Germans did.
Absolutely.
I think the function of those jokes were to laugh the horror in the face.
Some of them are extremely dark.
It's really gallows humor, as the British say.
I mean, there's for instance one very famous Jewish joke which is particularly dark about two Jews being executed.
And the guard says, you know, you will be shot.
And then all of a sudden he says you will be hung after all.
And one Jew says to the other look, they don't even have bullets anymore.
So it's a very, very dark joke, but in a way there's hope in it.
There's no hope for the protagonists of the joke.
They will be killed.
But there's hope for the Jewish people, because the enemy is running out of bullets and Hitler's mad plan is about to fail.
How did you get started investigating humor under Hitler?
Well, in the case of - I started out doing a documentary on the same subject, which actually was on air about two week ago in Germany with a very, very high audience.
And I saw that there was so much material there that I decided to do a book, too.
I talked to Auschwitz survivors.
I talked to people who were just normal people on the street or soldiers, and so on, asked them about the jokes that people told in the bunkers and so forth.
And there was a wealth of material, and it was actually - it did very well in Germany.
The book was sold out within four days, so you know, that is the situation at the moment.

This is a different country with a different culture and different standards.
And I think that she's probably trying to run it the best she can.

I do understand from my former military time, when you're in charge of something that ultimately, you know, the buck stops with the person in charge.
But, I mean, she hired some people and some people that didn't do what they were supposed to do.

I'm sure they'll be punished and I'm sure that she'll go on.
